definition:
The *center* of a group $G$ is the subgroup consisting of those elements
that commute with every other element. Formally,
$$\operatorname{Z}(G) = \{x \in G \mid xg = gx\hbox{ for all }g \in G\}.$$

It can be shown that the center has the following properties:

-   It is a normal subgroup (in fact, a characteristic subgroup).

-   It consists of those conjugacy classes containing just one element.

-   The center of an abelian group is the entire group.

-   For every prime $p$, every non-trivial finite has a non-trivial
    center. ()

A subgroup of the center of a group $G$ is called a *central subgroup*
of $G$. All central subgroups of $G$ are normal in $G$.

For any group $G$, the $G/\operatorname{Z}(G)$ is called the *central
quotient* of $G$, and is isomorphic to the inner automorphism group
$\operatorname{Inn}(G)$.
